source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_019_chunk1
evidence_span: The four primary Zircaloy fuel cladding deformation phenomena—axial elongation, circumferential creep, ovalization, and ridging-have been investigated for fuel irradiated in four modern pressurized water reactors.

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_019_chunk1
evidence_span: The axial elongation of fueled and nonfueled rods is examined by a regression fit for dependence on fluence, clad texture, yield stress, applied stress and, for fuel rods, fuel pellet length to diameter ratio.

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_019_chunk1
evidence_span: For fueled rods, only fluence and stress are found to be important

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_019_chunk1
evidence_span: For nonfueled rods, the texture is found to influence elongation.

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_019_chunk1
evidence_span: The circumferential creep strain data from nonfueled rods are also analyzed by a regression analysis to estimate the effects of time, flux, applied stress, temperature, yield stress, and texture.

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_019_chunk1
evidence_span: Time and flux have weaker than linear influence on strain, while the stress has a stronger than linear influence.

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_019_chunk1
evidence_span: The strain rate is almost athermal.

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_019_chunk1
evidence_span: The creep strain clearly increases with preirradiation yield strength.

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_019_chunk1
evidence_span: The primary difference is between recrystallized and stress-relief-annealed cladding with the degree of retained cold work having less effect.

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_019_chunk1
evidence_span: The creep rate clearly decreases with an increase in the angle between the basal poles and the radial direction.

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_019_chunk1
evidence_span: Ovalization of fueled and nonfueled rods is observed although analysis is difficult.

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_019_chunk1
evidence_span: Clad ridging develops in fueled rods, usually in a time period between one and two reactor cycles and almost always after three cycles.

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_019_chunk1
evidence_span: However, the maximum ridge height occurs before the end of two reactor cycles.

evidence_span: Each VDM tube was characterized by helical profilometry and ultrasonic measurement.

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_019_chunk2
evidence_span: The uncertainty in the measurement was $\pm 2 0 0 \ \mu \mathrm { m } .$

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_019_chunk2
evidence_span: This uncertainty was small compared with the $1 . 6 { \cdot } \mathsf { m m }$ uncertainty in the initial rod length.

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_019_chunk3
evidence_span: The independent variables considered include both operating variables (time, flux, stress, and temperature) and material properties variables (yield strength, texture, carbon content, fuel density, and pellet length-to-diameter ratio).

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_019_chunk3
evidence_span: A large effect of fluence on elongation is found in all cases.

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_019_chunk3
evidence_span: The power constant is larger for the fueled rods $( \sim 0 . 8 5 )$ than for the nonfueled CE rods $( \sim 0 . 6 4 )$.

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_019_chunk3
evidence_span: The power constant is larger for the fueled rods $( \sim 0 . 8 5 )$ than for the nonfueled CE rods $( \sim 0 . 6 4 )$.

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_019_chunk3
evidence_span: Only the circumferential cladding stress consistently reduced the standard deviation, and the exponent was close to 0.7 for both fueled and nonfueled rods.

evidence_span: Only the circumferential cladding stress consistently reduced the standard deviation, and the exponent was close to 0.7 for both fueled and nonfueled rods.

evidence_span: The circumferential creep data are taken from characterized nonfueled rods from the B&W and CE programs.

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_019_chunk5
evidence_span: The average diameters of 36 B&W rods (12 rods after each of the first three reactor cycles), measured at each of the lower 18 mandrels for each rod, are summarized® in Figs. 5 through 8.

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_019_chunk5
evidence_span: The diameters of nine CE rods (two EOC-1 and seven EOC-2 rods), measured at each of six or seven mandrel positions, are summarized® in Fig. 9.

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_019_chunk5
evidence_span: The complete data set is 648 B&W measurements and 60 CE measurements.

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_019_chunk5
evidence_span: The complete data set is 648 B&W measurements and 60 CE measurements.

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_019_chunk5
evidence_span: The carbon content of the cladding was included after out-of-pile tests by CE on SSM cladding [42] agreed with Charquet et al [43] that the thermal creep rate increases as carbon decreases.

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_019_chunk5
evidence_span: If there is an effect of carbon on creep, the effect is the opposite of that reported for the out-of-pile tests; that is, creep rate increases with increasing carbon, as discussed in Ref 42.

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_019_chunk5
evidence_span: The earliest measurements in the data set occur after approximately one year of irradiation.

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_019_chunk6
evidence_span: All rods show an increase in ovality with exposure. Initial ovalities usually do not exceed $2 5 \ \mu \mathrm { m }$ and the average initial ovality is on the order of $1 0 \mu \mathrm m$

evidence_span: average initial ovality is on the order of $1 0 \mu \mathrm m$

evidence_span: B&W nonfueled rods contained large gap regions for unrestricted ovalization to $\sim 1 2 6 0 – \mu \mathrm { m }$ ovality

evidence_span: CE nonfueled rods contained large gap regions for unrestricted ovalization to ${ \sim } 1 0 5 0 – \mu \mathrm { m }$ ovality

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_019_chunk8
evidence_span: The axial elongation of PWR fuel rods is greater than some previous investigations have found. The fluence exponent is 0.84

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_019_chunk8
evidence_span: Axial elongation is a function of applied stress. For a power function, the stress exponent is ~0.7

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_019_chunk8
evidence_span: Fuel ratcheting has little effect on the axial elongation of PWR fuel rods

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_019_chunk8
evidence_span: No effect of clad grain size on axial elongation or circumferential creep rate has been found

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_019_chunk8
evidence_span: No effect of clad grain size on axial elongation or circumferential creep rate has been found

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_019_chunk8
evidence_span: Increasing the angle (φ_max) between the location of the maximum of the basal poles in the radial-azimuthal plane and radial direction decreases both axial elongation and circumferential creep

evidence_span: Increasing the angle (φ_max) between the location of the maximum of the basal poles in the radial-azimuthal plane and radial direction decreases both axial elongation and circumferential creep

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_019_chunk9
evidence_span: A burst criterion model has been developed to calculate the burst data of Zircaloy claddings of a pressurized water reactor in a loss-of-coolant accident.

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_019_chunk9
evidence_span: The burst stress is assumed to depend on the temperature and oxygen concentration of the Zircaloy.

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_019_chunk9
evidence_span: single-rod transient burst tests in steam were performed using fuel rod simulators with indirect electric heating

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_019_chunk9
evidence_span: internal overpressure—10 to 140 bar

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_019_chunk9
evidence_span: heating rate—1 to $3 0 ~ \mathrm { \bf K } / s$

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_019_chunk9
evidence_span: The burst temperatures and burst strains predicted by the burst criterion model are in good agreement with the test data.

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_019_chunk9
evidence_span: The burst temperatures and burst strains predicted by the burst criterion model are in good agreement with the test data.
